text: 106 West 43rd Street, south side, west of Sixth Avenue. December, 1913.
123 West 43rd Street, north side, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. About 1914.

Sixth Ave., north from West 43rd Street to Central Park, and showing a general view northeast from the Bush Terminal Building (130 West 42nd Street, south side, between Sixth Ave. and Broadway). This view taken prior to the sudden building boom shows the Plaza Hotel, the Sherry Netherland, the Ritz Tower, St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas and B.F. Keith's Hippodrome (Sixth Ave., east side, between West 43rd and 44th Streets). Also shown are the Queensboro and the Hellgate R.R. Bridges.

May 1926.

Brown Brothers.

W 43rd Street, west from and across Sixth Avenue, as viewed from the Aeolian Hall, showing at Times Square the Paramount Building. In the lower right hand corner is the southwesterly corner of the Hippodrome. To the extreme left appears a portion of the Times Building. View No. 2 shows same in the center thereof. Prominently depicted in the latter is also the Bush Terminal Bldg. on 42nd Street. In the background is the North (Hudson) River and the Jersey Shore.

September 14, 1927.
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

W 43rd Street, west from and across Sixth Avenue, as viewed from the Aeolian Hall, showing at Times Square the Paramount Building. In the lower right hand corner is the southwesterly corner of the Hippodrome. To the extreme left appears a portion of the Times Building. View No. 2 shows same in the center thereof. Prominently depicted in the latter is also the Bush Terminal Bldg. on 42nd Street. In the background is the North (Hudson) River and the Jersey Shore.

September 14, 1927.
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, east side, from West 43rd
to 44th Street's, showing prominently the old Hippodrome. This structure erected about 1912, housed many famous productions, from pageants to talking pictures. Famous artists including Paderewski have played here. In 1922, Richard Strauss conducted a series of concerts with the Philadelphia Orchestra. Prior to its demolition in the Fall of 1939, it was a motion picture house. Various sport affairs wore held here.
View 1: March 9, 1929
2: May 27, 1930
3: May 1, 1933

Prior to its demolition in the Fall of 1939, it was a motion picture house. Various sport affairs wore held here.

Sixth Avenue, east side, from West 43rd
to 44th Street's, showing prominently the old Hippodrome. This structure erected about 1912, housed many famous productions, from pageants to talking pictures. Famous artists including Paderewski have played here. In 1922, Richard Strauss conducted a series of concerts with the Philadelphia Orchestra. View 1: March 9, 1929
2: May 27, 1930
3: May 1, 1933

West 43rd Street, north side, west from (No. 101), but not including Sixth Ave.

August 24, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Avenue, at the N. E. corner of W. 43rd Street, showing a portion of the Hippodrome, a theatrical structure under demolition. This is the first major real estate operation resulting from the recent razing of the Sixth Avenue "El".

Oct. 9, 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the Hippodrome occupying this frontage. As apparent, this land mark is under demolition and the site will be cleared for use as a parking lot. At the right margin is a portion of the R. C. A. Building.

September 17, 1939

George Jiranek
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the Hippodrome under demolition.

Sept. 20, 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the Hippodrome under demolition. Note the pavement of the Avenue, which at this date is still going thru subway construction, car tracks remain, tho busses have replaced the former surface cars.

November 1, 1939

Gift of George Jiranek
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

Sixth Avenue, at the N. E. corner of W. 43rd Street, showing the southwesterly corner of the Hippodrome.

Nov. 1, 1939

Gift of George Jiranek
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the former Hippodrome site. This has been cleared and will be utilized as an automobile parking lot. The photographer is viewing southeastward towards buildings on the north side of 44th Street that are east of the Avenue.

November 15, 1939

Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

(1)
East side of Sixth Avenue showing the Hippodrome Entrance. Between 43rd and 44th streets.
(2)
Sixth Avenue east side Hipprodrome between 43rd and 44th Street, from El platform.
P.L.Speer.
NO REPRODUCTION.  September 8, 1939.

(1)
East side of Sixth Avenue showing the Hippodrome Entrance. Between 43rd and 44th streets.
(2)
Sixth Avenue east side Hipprodrome between 43rd and 44th Street, from El platform.
P.L.Speer.
NO REPRODUCTION.  September 8, 1939.

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West 43rd Street, showing the Hippodrome and Rockefeller Center buildings. The former, shown solely in View 2, is shortly to be demolished and its site utilized as an automobile parking lot.

View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: September 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from West 43rd Street, showing the Hippodrome and Rockefeller Center buildings. The former, shown solely in View 2, is shortly to be demolished and its site utilized as an automobile parking lot.

View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: September 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, west side, from West 44th (center) to 43rd Streets. This photograph, taken from the east side of the Avenue is in a southwestern direction to show towering structures at 42nd Street. They are the dominant Bush Building and the No. 113 W. 42nd Street Building.

View 2 is photographed across the parking lot where the former Hippodrome stood. The low 6th Avenue buildings in this view are at 43rd Street. To the left is a portion of Stern's Department Store. The white 33-story, No. 1441 Broadway Building is included.

View 1: April 5, 1939
View 2: May 1940

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, west side, from West 44th (center) to 43rd Streets. This photograph, taken from the east side of the Avenue is in a southwestern direction to show towering structures at 42nd Street. They are the dominant Bush Building and the No. 113 W. 42nd Street Building.

View 2 is photographed across the parking lot where the former Hippodrome stood. The low 6th Avenue buildings in this view are at 43rd Street. To the left is a portion of Stern's Department Store. The white 33-story, No. 1441 Broadway Building is included.

View 1: April 5, 1939
View 2: May 1940

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, from West 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the low buildings on the west side, as viewed across the former Hippodrome site. The latter has become the parking lot shown. This occupies the easterly frontage of the Avenue. Times Square and Broadway are just beyond, distinguished by the dominant Paramount Building. Various hotels are on the side streets. Observable are the 44th Street Hotel, the Hotel Langwell, the Peerless and the St. James. View 3 is northwestward towards W. 44th Street.

May 5, 1940
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, from West 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the low buildings on the west side, as viewed across the former Hippodrome site. The latter has become the parking lot shown. This occupies the easterly frontage of the Avenue. Times Square and Broadway are just beyond, distinguished by the dominant Paramount Building. Various hotels are on the side streets. Observable are the 44th Street Hotel, the Hotel Langwell, the Peerless and the St. James. View 3 is northwestward towards W. 44th Street.

May 5, 1940
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, from West 43rd to 44th Streets, showing the low buildings on the west side, as viewed across the former Hippodrome site. The latter has become the parking lot shown. This occupies the easterly frontage of the Avenue. Times Square and Broadway are just beyond, distinguished by the dominant Paramount Building. Various hotels are on the side streets. Observable are the 44th Street Hotel, the Hotel Langwell, the Peerless and the St. James. View 3 is northwestward towards W. 44th Street.

May 5, 1940
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr

(1) West 43rd Street, north side, looking westwards from near Sixth Avenue. On left may be seen Henry Miller Theatre. On right Hotel Woodstock across Broadway maybe seen the clock on Tower of Paramount Building.

(2) West 43rd Street, east of Broadway showing the Midtown Bus Terminal Station. Neg. No. A-898

P. L. Sperr

View 1: May, 1940
View 2: July 23, 1940

(1) West 43rd Street, north side, looking westwards from near Sixth Avenue. On left may be seen Henry Miller Theatre. On right Hotel Woodstock across Broadway maybe seen the clock on Tower of Paramount Building.

(2) West 43rd Street, east of Broadway showing the Midtown Bus Terminal Station. Neg. No. A-898

P. L. Sperr

View 1: May, 1940
View 2: July 23, 1940

Sixth Avenue, e.s., n. fr. 43rd Street.

Neg. no. A-1290

P. L. Sperr, photographer
July 15, 1941
